displayed_text: Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: You know whether we’ve completely treated a couple of men and now we’re waiting to go up or whether or not we’re ready to go right now. So that would be a slot availability. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Your thoughts or questions about that? Patient: Well you’re going to coordinate with Dr. G. Doctor: I will coordinate with him the sort of the decision about have you progressed. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then I’ll print out these consent forms for you that you can take and sort of that he can look at as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we can sort of decide which one makes more sense for you, or none of them may make any sense, and that really because your scans or worse, you’re having more symptoms. You know the textbook answer right now is go to chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm. Patient: And how soon would that start?

Patient: The only e-mail that I got was a confirmation that they had received my test. Family Member: But that was the only thing, right? Not that that’s a small thing, but that was – there was no other genetic, uh, information. Doctor: Actually, I gave you the wrong information. I’m sorry. So, it’s actually a higher chance that they inherit it because it’s --- I, I forgot this is what’s called – so there’s two kinds of mutations; dominant and recessive. So, recessive means you have to, uh, uh, get, uh, two bad copies to – I want to say it’s a twenty-five percent chance because you have to get two bad copies. But, in this case, if you get one bad copy, you are at risk even though you have one good copy. So, in that case, it sort of takes out your, the mother. So, they, they have a fifty percent chance of getting this gene from you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, uh, so if they get it, they’re at risk, and if they don’t get it – so, it’s a fifty-fifty as opposed to a recessive where they have a fifty percent chance from you and a fifty percent chance from the mother, and they have to get two copies to have a problem. Patient: Okay. But – Doctor: So, that makes it twenty-five percent. Patient: If they are negative ---- Doctor: If they’re negative, they’re negative. Patient: It’s over. Doctor: It’s over. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Uhm and you’re in remission unless it recurs, comes back. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Last question, or uh maybe not. Mistletoe. I’ve had some friends that have said maybe that can help with side effects, things of that nature. If I were to research that, would that in any way – Doctor: Yeah, well thanks for asking that, so mistletoe is contraindicated certainly during chemo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it interferes with chem. I would say also during radiation.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. And the chemo is what we’re here to talk about today- Patient: Okay. Doctor: It is you know if you’re still interested in the clinical trial, have questions for me about the clinical trial, then I’m going to bring D___ in. So she’s the research nurse that I’ll sort of is it doable, can we get started, and what you have to do to go forward, okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once you guys sign the paperwork and we move forward, then you and I will pick a date to pick the day the chemo starts. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The computer makes the decision as to whether you get the extra drug or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And there always is the possibility that when you go through some of this checking, you’re not eligible. Patient: Um. Doctor: Okay, I think we have ninety days from when you got your first shot, which was November six or seven – Patient: Um hum.

Family Member: So do you have any experience with the BET inhibitor? Have you seen it work or is it so new that you don’t really know? Doctor: I have experience with a different BET inhibitor. So not this particular one. (Coughs) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -was an injection type of BET inhibitor. This one is a pill. So I think uh, no I really don’t have too much experience with this particular one. The study just opened frankly – Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: -- and now we have two or three people who will probably start right around the same time. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There is some unknowns, quite a bit of unknowns, in terms of what side effects to expect. There is the possibility of – obviously we’ll be monitoring your kidney function, liver function, all of that pretty closely and be monitoring you for any side effects. I mean you tell me more than what anybody knows about this medication sometimes. But uh for the most part it seems to have been okay tolerated in the very, very preliminary, very few patients that have been on it. Patient: What about the diabetes? How does that fit in to this discussion? Doctor: We will have to see if it affects sugars and then accordingly adjust your medications for the diabetes. But right now I don’t know for sure that it does or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be monitoring glucose every time anyway. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Next time we’ll bring it all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: My daughter-in-law, daughter-in-law works for F____. Doctor: Okay. So this is just to help with eye health? Patient: Well, my macular degeneration. Doctor: Yeah, typically, it’s okay. That works I think okay. I’m talking about the other stuff. You go to GNC. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And things like that where it looks good in the bottle but there’s no regulation on what’s inside. Remember we talked about how difficult that can be sometimes? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And then I don’t know what’s going to happen if your liver poops out on me then we’re in trouble. Family Member: Right. Because it can affect his liver. Patient: Okay. And that was the same thing with the magnesium. Right?

Family Member: - and my aunt has seizures Doctor: Oh. Family Member: And sometimes I have to keep her from swallowing her tongue- Doctor: That’s it. Yeah- Family Member: -by putting the spoon under there, so just letting it flow through. Doctor: -and again point six percent chance is really rare, but it’s probably if I look at all the side effect list it’s the one that would scare me the most if I was reading that form, Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: so I want to share it with you guys. Other than that, this is not like chemo. This is not like anything else. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: So the tiredness is the top three that really will be wiping you out. Sometimes it makes you feel so wiped out… Patient: Wait a minute, W__ I got a compliment for you Healthcare Professional: Uh, huh?

Family Member: Mm, hmn. Doctor: But that would be potentially something you could participate in. Right now I would be a little bit worried about putting you on it with these gasping things that I can’t explain- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: because it might affect our ability to get the therapy in. Uhm, we have another study which I, uh - Transformer - we have a first-in-human study of a drug that comes from plum seeds. In laboratory studies it looks like it can attack and kill prostate cancer cells. So this is a study where we’re looking at a drug that now is in I.V. form to see how often does it affect the PSA, how often do you get side effects that we can’t give it to you. So it’s more about the side effects and whether it helps you or not. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Some of the data says that it could help you, but we don’t know. We’ve never given it to enough men. We treat a number of men and if they do okay, then we go to a higher dose. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah.

Patient: So you don’t want me to take Xtandi at all anymore? Healthcare Professional: No, stop it. Family Member: Can we donate it to somebody that needs it? Healthcare Professional: Yeah, bring it back in. Doctor: Bring it back to us and we’ll make sure it gets recycled to the next person, absolutely. Family Member: To the next person who needs it. Doctor: And we have a process to do that. Family Member: Somebody that needs it because I know how expensive it is. Doctor: Yes, and we appreciate that. Family Member: Yeah, we’ll bring it back. Doctor: Okay, sounds like a plan. Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything?

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If patients are a Gleason score of eight or more, high risk of progression. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If it’s a Gleason score of seven I would consider that and intermediate risk and a Gleason score of seven Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Two ways of having a Gleason score of seven. Three plus four is seven or equals seven. Those two um numbers are different depending Gleason if Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if the majority of your Gleason pattern is higher than tree, and the small minority is higher than four, since you have more of the four and less then the three to more Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you are a lot more than then they’re gonna Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So you have an intermediate risk, but potentially . Okay?

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and uh this will allow me use with along with our other researchers for future use. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um so you can see it was important for me to talk to the radiologist to make sure that we can do it safely and that we can get enough samples to make it worth everybody’s while. Okay. Questions. Patient: Um n- well observations. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They – it it did say for example… Doctor: Mhmm. Patient: …gall bladder, fossa, largest not quite two centimeters… Doctor: Right. Patient: …which is not quite an inch. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I do understand the sample thing because…

Patient: I don’t have to go and come back next week. Doctor: Okay. All right, well then, so you know what we can do then if you're if you're comfortable. Let me make sure that we went over everything too because Patient: I’m comfortable. That’s the way I am. Doctor: Let me go, let me just make sure you're a volunteer. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yeah, your participation will obviously not affect your clinical care. We're going to collect biospecimens as part of this so your blood, you can find this study online. We talked about the muscadine grape skin and that we don't know for sure if this works or not, that's why we're testing it and obviously we follow your PSA. So yeah, so 80 people total are going to be in it. Alright, so the first part that we need to do this pre screening is and we do need you to sign is to get the blood test drawn to see if you're eligible for it. So if you're agreeable to at least that part then we can do that today. Okay, all right. So this means that this at least then you won't be charged for the test. Do you want that? Patient: Yes. Family Member: So how long is this? I mean once we starts it. What will they do? Doctor: So you come back every month, and we’ll see you initially- you report any side effects. And the way that this usually works is that well, for any treatment, we continue the treatment until either disease progression, meaning that your disease is getting worse despite the treatments of the treatments not working anymore, or unacceptable toxicity. So if you have really bad side effects, we're not going to continue the treatment. Patient: Right. Doctor: So this Yeah, so this one is talking about your risks of discomfort. The most common one is gassiness. So you might not be the most pleasant person to be around while you're taking this, but that's, I mean, it's only 8%. So it's not really that common, but most people usually do fine there. Been no serious side effects. So, you know, it's very safe for us it doesn't cost anything there are no extra costs it's just what would be done in normal clinical care anyways is what they've done anything that would be extra that's like not covered by insurance like this blood test, to check your genotype it’s covered by the study. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You don't get paid to join the study, you can leave at any time to protect your privacy, you do tend to get parking tickets, so that like you know, when you come visits okay and then these are the this is the contact information for our clinic.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, that’s why they can see scarring on CAT scans, but that’s just again, inflammation. Um. And they love to use . And then, the only change that we see is in your right adrenal gland. Patient: MM, hmm. Doctor: And they’re saying there’s a nodular appearance, and there’s inflammation around it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so, they don’t know what it is. I went up there. That’s why I wasn’t in right when you got here ‘cuz I wanted to go over it with the radiologist. Like, can you tell me what you think it is, and they don’t know. They’re hedging. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: It could be a cancer spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or it could be that you bled into your adrenal gland, and so, uh, hemorrhaged into the adrenal gland. Was that your aspirin? You know, I don’t know why people do that. But you can spontaneously do that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Is it a side effect of the drug? I don’t know. But is it a cancer spot? Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Essentially again with the shot and stuff, it didn’t change. Doctor: Exactly. No. You’re great. You had the last shot June sixth. You’re fine with that. So we’re going to extend it a week or two. Patient: Going to the bathroom. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. You’re eating fine. Patient: I’m eating fine. I’m eating good. Patient: I’m going to eat right now. Doctor: Oh. You’re taking her to lunch? Patient: Yeah. I’m taking her to lunch. Doctor: That’s nice. Where you guys going? Patient: Downtown somewhere. Doctor: Oh. Did you check out the, the, S___ S___? Do you guys ever go in there? Family Member: No. Doctor: It’s really good.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Oh my gosh what uh what uh… Family Member: At the G__ Doctor: What do you do? Family Member: Dosimetrist. Doctor: Oh wow. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Wow! Small world. Maybe my husband was in training in radiation oncology. Maybe you know him. Family Member: I think so. Doctor: Yeah because (laughs) Patient: Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: You know that was twenty some years ago so that’s probably about right. Family Member: That is.
